text.p: Testimony was due to continue on Wednesday in the third and final phase of grocery store chain Food Lion Inc's lawsuit against the ABC television network with jurors hearing more evidence on punitive damages.
Food Lion sued ABC and four producers of its newsmagazine show "PrimeTime Live" for a 1992 program that claimed the grocer sold old food and repackaged out-of-date merchandise.

Salisbury, N.C.-based Food Lion charged the ABC producers who worked undercover at two Food Lion stores with fraud, deceptive trade practices, conspiracy and breach of duty of loyalty. It argued that while employed by the store the producers were obligated to ensure sanitary practices.
In the current punitive damages phase of the trial -- in federal court in Greensboro, N.C. -- witnesses for Food Lion said the program hurt the grocer but won ABC the season's rating "sweeps."
ABC was expected to present its case Wednesday and Thursday before a jury decides whether to award punitive damages.

Previously the jury found New York-based ABC, a unit of Walt Disney Co, and its producers had committed fraud, trespass and breach of employee loyalty in the undercover investigation and awarded the grocer $1,402 in actual damages.
